ai-mn122:1.2_0: at one time the Fortunate One was dwelling amongst the Sakyas, near to Kapilavatthu, in Nigrodha’s Monastery.
ai-mn122:2.1_0: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kapilavatthu for alms.
ai-mn122:2.2_0: He wandered for alms in Kapilavatthu. After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to the Kapilavatthu for the day’s meditation.
ai-mn122:2.3_0: Now at that time many resting places had been spread out at Kāḷakhemaka’s dwelling.
ai-mn122:2.4_0: The Buddha saw many resting places
ai-mn122:2.5_0: and after seeing (him), this occurred to the Fortunate One:
ai-mn122:2.6_0: “Many resting places have been spread out;
ai-mn122:2.7_0: are there many mendicants living here?”
ai-mn122:2.8_0: Now at that time Venerable Ānanda, together with many other mendicants, was making robes in Ghaṭa the Sakyan’s dwelling.
ai-mn122:2.9_0: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to Ghaṭa’s dwelling.
ai-mn122:2.9_1: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-mn122:2.10_0: While sat the Fortunate One addressed venerable Ānanda, (saying):
ai-mn122:2.11_0: “Many resting places have been spread out at Kāḷakhemaka’s dwelling;
ai-mn122:2.13_0: “Sir, Many resting places have been spread out;
ai-mn122:2.15_0: It’s currently the time for making robes.”
ai-mn122:3.1_0: “Ānanda, a mendicant doesn’t shine who enjoys company and groups, who loves them and likes to enjoy them.
ai-mn122:3.2_0: It’s simply not possible that such a mendicant will get the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
ai-mn122:3.3_0: But it is possible that a mendicant who lives alone, withdrawn from the group will get the bliss of renunciation, the bliss of seclusion, the bliss of peace, the bliss of awakening when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
ai-mn122:4.1_0: It’s simply not possible that such a mendicant will enter and remain in the company of company and groups.
ai-mn122:4.2_0: But it is possible that a mendicant who lives alone, withdrawn from the group will enter and remain in the freedom of heart—either that which is temporary and pleasant, or that which is irreversible and unshakable.
ai-mn122:5.1_0: I don’t see any such form decay and perish.
ai-mn122:6.1_0: But the meditation of a Realized One is awakened.
ai-mn122:6.2_0: to enter and remain in emptiness internally by not focusing on any signs.
ai-mn122:6.3_0: Now, suppose that while the Realized One is practicing this meditation, monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, rulers and their ministers, founders of religious sects and their disciples go to visit him.
ai-mn122:6.4_0: In that case, with a mind slanting, sloping, and inclining to seclusion, withdrawn, and loving renunciation, he invariably gives each of them a talk emphasizing the topic of dismissal.
ai-mn122:7.1_0: Therefore, if a mendicant might wish:
ai-mn122:7.2_0: ‘May I enter and remain in emptiness internally!’ So they should still, settle, unify, and immerse their mind in samādhi internally.
ai-mn122:7.3_0: And how does a mendicant settle their mind internally?
ai-mn122:8.1_0: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption ...
ai-mn122:8.4_0: dwells having attained the fourth absorption.
ai-mn122:8.5_0: That’s how a mendicant directes their mind internally, immerses it in samādhi internally.
ai-mn122:9.2_0: but their mind isn’t eager, confident, settled, and decided.
ai-mn122:9.4_0: ‘I am focusing on emptiness internally, but my mind isn’t eager, confident, settled, and decided.’
ai-mn122:9.5_0: In this way he’s aware of the situation.
ai-mn122:9.7_0: They focus on emptiness internally and externally ...
ai-mn122:9.9_0: but their mind isn’t eager, confident, settled, and decided.
ai-mn122:9.11_0: ‘I am focusing on the imperturbable internally, but my mind isn’t eager, confident, settled, and decided.’
ai-mn122:9.12_0: In this way he’s aware of the situation.
ai-mn122:10.1_0: That mendicant should direct their mind just one’s mind in such a way that they should still, settle, unify, and immerse it in samādhi.
ai-mn122:10.3_0: and their mind is eager, confident, settled, and decided.
ai-mn122:10.5_0: ‘I am focusing on emptiness internally, and my mind is eager, confident, settled, and decided.’
ai-mn122:10.6_0: In this way he’s aware of the situation.
ai-mn122:10.8_0: They focus on emptiness internally and externally ...
ai-mn122:10.10_0: and their mind is eager, confident, settled, and decided.
ai-mn122:10.12_0: ‘I am focusing on the imperturbable, and my mind is eager, confident, settled, and decided.’
ai-mn122:10.13_0: In this way he’s aware of the situation.
ai-mn122:11.1_0: While a mendicant is practicing such meditation, if their mind inclines to walking, they walk mindfully, thinking:
ai-mn122:11.2_0: ‘While I’m walking mindful, bad, unskillful qualities of desire and aversion will not overwhelm me.’
ai-mn122:11.3_0: In this way he’s aware of the situation.
ai-mn122:11.4_0: While a mendicant is practicing such meditation, if their mind inclines to standing, they stand, thinking:
ai-mn122:11.5_0: ‘While I’m standing, bad, unskillful qualities of desire and aversion will not overwhelm me.’
ai-mn122:11.6_0: In this way he’s aware of the situation.
ai-mn122:11.7_0: While a mendicant is practicing such meditation, if their mind inclines to sitting, they sit, thinking:
ai-mn122:11.8_0: ‘While I’m sitting, bad, unskillful qualities of desire and aversion will not overwhelm me.’
ai-mn122:11.9_0: In this way he’s aware of the situation.
ai-mn122:11.10_0: While a mendicant is practicing such meditation, if their mind inclines to lying down, they lie down, thinking:
ai-mn122:11.11_0: ‘While I’m lying down, bad, unskillful qualities of desire and aversion will not overwhelm me.’
ai-mn122:11.12_0: In this way he’s aware of the situation.
ai-mn122:12.1_0: While a mendicant is practicing such meditation, if their mind inclines to talking, they think:
ai-mn122:12.2_0: ‘I will not engage in the kind of speech that is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. Such speech doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. Namely: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.’
ai-mn122:12.3_0: In this way he’s aware of the situation.
ai-mn122:12.4_0: But a disciple should value following the Teacher, even if asked to go away, for the sake of talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart and leads solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That is, talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.
ai-mn122:12.5_0: In this way he’s aware of the situation.
ai-mn122:13.1_0: While a mendicant is practicing such meditation, if their mind inclines to thinking, they think:
ai-mn122:13.2_0: ‘I will not think the kind of thought that is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. Such thoughts don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That is, sensual, malicious, or cruel thoughts.’
ai-mn122:13.3_0: In this way he’s aware of the situation.
ai-mn122:13.4_0: But the thought that is noble and emancipating, and leads one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. That is, thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.
ai-mn122:13.4_1: ‘I will think the kind of thought.’
ai-mn122:13.5_0: In this way he’s aware of the situation.
ai-mn122:14.1_0: Ānanda, there are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
ai-mn122:14.3_0: Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-mn122:14.7_0: Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-mn122:14.8_0: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
ai-mn122:15.1_0: where a mendicant should check their own mind.
ai-mn122:15.2_0: ‘Is there any of these five kinds of sensual stimulation that arises in me or one of these five kinds of sensual stimulation?’
ai-mn122:15.3_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:
ai-mn122:15.4_0: ‘I have some of these five kinds of sensual stimulation.’
ai-mn122:15.6_0: ‘I have not given up desire and greed for the five kinds of sensual stimulation.’
ai-mn122:15.7_0: In this way he’s aware of the situation.
ai-mn122:15.8_0: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:
ai-mn122:15.9_0: ‘I have no more sensual pleasures than these five kinds of sensual stimulation.’
ai-mn122:15.11_0: ‘I have given up desire and greed for the five kinds of sensual stimulation.’
ai-mn122:15.12_0: In this way he’s aware of the situation.
ai-mn122:16.1_0: A mendicant should meditate observing rise and fall in these five grasping aggregates:
ai-mn122:16.2_0: ‘Such is form, such is the origination of form, such is the passing away of form;
ai-mn122:16.5_0: Such are choices, such is the origin of choices, such is the ending of choices.
ai-mn122:16.6_0: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’
ai-mn122:17.1_0: As they do so, they give up the conceit ‘I am’ regarding the five grasping aggregates.
ai-mn122:17.3_0: ‘I have given up the conceit “I am” regarding the five grasping aggregates.’
ai-mn122:17.4_0: In this way he’s aware of the situation.
ai-mn122:18.1_0: These principles are entirely skillful, with skillful outcomes; they are noble, transcendent, and inaccessible to the Wicked One.
ai-mn122:19.2_0: What advantage is worthy of reference to the Teacher?”
ai-mn122:19.3_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha.
ai-mn122:19.3_1: He is our guide and our refuge.
ai-mn122:19.3_2: The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
ai-mn122:20.1_0: “Ānanda, it’s not easy for someone who is worthy of an offering incompetent teaching to the Teacher.
ai-mn122:20.3_0: For a long time, Ānanda, you have properly heard that
ai-mn122:20.4_0: But a disciple should value following the Teacher, even if asked to go away, for the sake of talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart and leads solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That is, talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.
ai-mn122:21.1_0: This being so, Ānanda, there is a peril for the teacher, a peril for the student, and a peril for a spiritual practitioner.
ai-mn122:22.1_0: And how is there a peril for the teacher?
ai-mn122:22.2_0: Take some teacher who frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
ai-mn122:22.3_0: While meditating withdrawn, he’s visited by a stream of brahmins and householders of the city and country.
ai-mn122:22.4_0: When this happens, they enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence.
ai-mn122:22.5_0: This teacher is said to be imperiled by the teacher’s peril.
ai-mn122:22.6_0: They’re ruined by bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupted, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
ai-mn122:22.7_0: That’s how there is a peril for the teacher.
ai-mn122:23.1_0: And how is there a peril for the student?
ai-mn122:23.2_0: But a disciple of this teacher, emulating their teacher’s fostering of seclusion,
ai-mn122:23.3_0: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
ai-mn122:23.4_0: While meditating withdrawn, he’s visited by a stream of brahmins and householders of the city and country.
ai-mn122:23.5_0: When this happens, they enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence.
ai-mn122:23.6_0: This is called the student Upavāna.
ai-mn122:23.7_0: They’re ruined by bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupted, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
ai-mn122:23.8_0: That’s how there is a peril for the student.
ai-mn122:24.1_0: And how is there a peril for a spiritual practitioner?
ai-mn122:24.2_0: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
ai-mn122:24.3_0: So they frequent a secluded lodging.
ai-mn122:24.4_0: While meditating withdrawn, he’s visited by a stream of brahmins and householders of the city and country.
ai-mn122:24.5_0: When this happens, they don’t enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence.
ai-mn122:24.6_0: But a disciple of this teacher, emulating their teacher’s fostering of seclusion,
ai-mn122:24.7_0: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
ai-mn122:24.8_0: While meditating withdrawn, he’s visited by a stream of brahmins and householders of the city and country.
ai-mn122:24.9_0: When this happens, they enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence.
ai-mn122:24.10_0: This spiritual practitioner is said to be imperiled by the spiritual practitioner’s peril.
ai-mn122:24.11_0: They’re ruined by bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupted, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
ai-mn122:24.12_0: That’s how there is a peril for a spiritual practitioner.
ai-mn122:24.13_0: And in this context, Ānanda, as compared to the peril of the teacher or the student, the peril of the spiritual practitioner has more painful, bitter results, and even leads to the underworld.
ai-mn122:25.1_0: So, Ānanda, when I was treated me as an enemy,
ai-mn122:25.2_0: That will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.
ai-mn122:25.3_0: And how do disciples treat their Teacher as an enemy, not a friend?
ai-mn122:25.4_0: It’s when the Teacher teaches the Dhamma out of kindness and compassion:
ai-mn122:25.5_0: ‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’
ai-mn122:25.6_0: But their disciples don’t want to listen. They don’t pay attention or apply their minds to understand. They proceed having turned away from the Teacher’s instruction.
ai-mn122:25.7_0: That’s how the disciples treat their Teacher as a friend, not an enemy.
ai-mn122:26.1_0: And how do disciples treat their Teacher as an enemy, not an enemy?
ai-mn122:26.2_0: It’s when the Teacher teaches the Dhamma out of kindness and compassion:
ai-mn122:26.3_0: ‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’
ai-mn122:26.4_0: And their disciples want to listen. They pay attention and apply their minds to understand. They don’t proceed having turned away from the Teacher’s instruction.
ai-mn122:26.5_0: That’s how the disciples treat their Teacher as a friend, not an enemy.
ai-mn122:26.6_0: So, Ānanda, when I was treated me as an enemy,
ai-mn122:26.7_0: That will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.
ai-mn122:27.1_0: I shall not mollycoddle you like a potter with their damp, unfired pots.
ai-mn122:27.2_0: I shall speak, correcting you again and again,
ai-mn122:27.4_0: The core will stand the test.”
ai-mn122:27.5_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn122:27.6_0: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Buddha said.
